articles.headline: A Watch That Sinks Under Its Features
articles.snippet: Samsung’s Galaxy Gear watch is ambitious and even amazing. But it has too many components for one gadget.
articles.abstract: Samsung’s Galaxy Gear watch is ambitious and even amazing. But it has too many components for one gadget.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the beginning, computers were the size of buildings. To use one, you walked into it.

articles.headline: Jury Clears Promoter in Death of Michael Jackson
articles.snippet: The jury’s verdict saves A.E.G. Live, the world’s second-largest concert company, from paying what could have been huge damages.
articles.abstract: The jury’s verdict saves A.E.G. Live, the world’s second-largest concert company, from paying what could have been huge damages.
articles.lead_paragraph: A California jury decided on Wednesday that Michael Jackson’s final concert promoter, A.E.G. Live, was not responsible for the pop star’s death.

articles.headline: As F.B.I. Pursued Snowden, an E-Mail Service Stood Firm
articles.snippet: A federal judge unsealed documents in a case involving a tech entrepreneur who refused to give the government broad access to data on users of Lavabit, his secure e-mail service, one of whom was Edward J. Snowden.
articles.abstract: A federal judge unsealed documents in a case involving a tech entrepreneur who refused to give the government broad access to data on users of Lavabit, his secure e-mail service, one of whom was Edward J. Snowden.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — One day last May, Ladar Levison returned home to find an F.B.I. agent’s business card on his Dallas doorstep. So began a four-month tangle with law enforcement officials that would end with Mr. Levison’s shutting the business he had spent a decade building and becoming an unlikely hero of privacy advocates in their escalating battle with the government over Internet security.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Social Networks in a Battle for the Second Screen
articles.snippet: Facebook and Twitter are vying to become the nation’s digital water cooler as they woo networks and advertisers.
articles.abstract: Facebook and Twitter are vying to become the nation’s digital water cooler as they woo networks and advertisers.
articles.lead_paragraph: After “Breaking Bad” drew 10.3 million viewers to one of the most crowd-satisfying finales in television history on Sunday, Twitter and Facebook raced to tell the news media about the throngs who shared their instant reactions to the show on the social networks.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: UBS Brokers in Puerto Rico Create Headache for the Bank
articles.snippet: The Swiss banking giant, which manages $10 billion for the American commonwealth’s millionaires, began an internal investigation into the lending practices of some of its top-producing brokers.
articles.abstract: The Swiss banking giant, which manages $10 billion for the American commonwealth’s millionaires, began an internal investigation into the lending practices of some of its top-producing brokers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the years, Puerto Rico has attracted the very wealthy, who come for the postcard-perfect beaches and the promise of a tax-free life.

articles.headline: Wall St. Fears Go Beyond Shutdown
articles.snippet: The prospect of Congress failing to raise the nation’s debt limit has economists and investors exploring options the White House might have.
articles.abstract: The prospect of Congress failing to raise the nation’s debt limit has economists and investors exploring options the White House might have.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Washington preoccupied by the government shutdown, Wall Street is shifting its attention to an even more worrisome situation: the possibility that the government could run out of money within the next few weeks, forcing an unprecedented default on its debt.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: In Showdown With G.O.P., a Scrappy Reid Plays Hardball
articles.snippet: Convinced he has no viable Republican partners on either side of the Capitol, Senator Harry Reid has used aggressive tactics to try to force his opponents to crack over the government shutdown.
articles.abstract: Convinced he has no viable Republican partners on either side of the Capitol, Senator Harry Reid has used aggressive tactics to try to force his opponents to crack over the government shutdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was not enough for Senator Harry Reid to just dismiss Republican offers as “vexatious” or “kid’s stuff” or “one cockamamie, can’t-pass idea after another.” He called the White House and asked it to issue a veto threat, which it promptly did.

articles.headline: Migrants Die as Burning Boat Capsizes Off Italy
articles.snippet: The deaths of at least 111 people again underscored the dangerous, desperate efforts by many in Africa and the Middle East to reach Europe.
articles.abstract: The deaths of at least 111 people again underscored the dangerous, desperate efforts by many in Africa and the Middle East to reach Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Having floated for at least two days in the choppy Mediterranean Sea to reach Europe, a rickety trawler overstuffed with African migrants fleeing war and poverty was nearing a Sicilian island, not even a quarter-mile away. But it was still dark and no one had yet spotted them. So to signal their position, someone set a match to a blanket.
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and Elisabetta Povoledo

articles.headline: Boehner Pledges to Avoid Default, Republicans Say
articles.snippet: Speaker John A. Boehner has privately told Republican lawmakers anxious about fallout from the government shutdown that he would not allow a potentially more crippling federal default.
articles.abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner has privately told Republican lawmakers anxious about fallout from the government shutdown that he would not allow a potentially more crippling federal default.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner has privately told Republican lawmakers anxious about fallout from the government shutdown that he would not allow a potentially more crippling federal default as the atmosphere on Capitol Hill turned increasingly tense on Thursday.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Annie Lowrey
